Fields.DialogueText: Woah!
I'm impressed. You managed to pull off tripping in style, La Motte-Picquet.
Merci, Capitaine! I've been told I'm graceful.
It would appear as such.
Oh, and désolée for bumping into you. I was too busy reading my book to see you.

Fields.MenuText: Reading and walking is unsafe. You need to look up in the future.
No harm done. What are you reading, anyway?
A part of me feels as though you aren't really sorry.

Fields.DialogueText: If bumping into someone is the worst that can happen, I'll take my chances.
Brave New World. Science fiction, though more... pessimistic than you'd expect.
Well, I don't regret it, if that's what you're insinuating. I finished the chapter I was on, after all.
So, where are you headed?
To see you, actually.
What for?
No time for questions! Morganas inbound!
@BATTLE
It would seem you are as lithe in battle as you are at tripping.
Flattery will get you nowhere, Capitaine.
Maybe if I were reading a book while I flattered you.
Yes, yes, drive your point home. Let me give you a proposal in exchange. You may have noticed my penchant for photography.
Now that you mention it, I don't think I've ever seen you without that camera.
Nor will you ever. This war is the defining moment of your civilization. I intend to document it. For students of history, my project will be the next best thing to time travel.
I'm interested. Though I must have missed your proposal.
I concede that a better word would have been "announcement." Maybe "warning," but that depends on you.
Let's stick with "announcement." I'm intrigued.
Wonderful! I'll keep you posted.
At least she can't bump into anyone with a camera... can she?
Capitaine!
*CLICK*
Wha--? Did you take a picture of me?
Oui!
Um... why?
To add another picture to my photo series. It's tentatively called "Personal Space."
What exactly are you trying to capture?
I want the genuine reactions and emotions on people's faces. Candid shots are called for.
How many others have you captured?
Only a few crew members, but I will soon collect them all.

Fields.MenuText: So you've been stalking me?
Why didn't you take the picture right before you pitched this to me?
Is that why you didn't tell me what you wanted the other day?

Fields.DialogueText: Not stalking, per se. I was just waiting for a moment wherein I had seen you, but you hadn't seen me.
Because the reaction wouldn't have been genuine.
Oui! I did not want to spoil the surprise when I found you later.
Well... I do hope the picture turns out nice.
I'm optimistic, Capitaine. Film is precious, so I must make each shot count.
@BATTLE
Speaking of...
Bonjour!
*CLICK*
Would you stop taking pictures of me?
But you're such a great subject!
*CLICK*
And you're such a bother.
What did you call me?!
Um... I-- wha--?
Apologize, this instant. There was no need to call me names. I was only taking your picture.
I'm... sorry?
You're forgiven. And I apologize for taking your picture, even after you told me to stop. I know I can get carried away sometimes.
La Motte-Picquet! We have Morganas headed this way!
@BATTLE
You know, I saw that encounter you had earlier. You seemed really upset for a minute there.
I know I have a bit of a temper. But I do make an effort to apologize when I realize I've gone too far.
You're a peculiar one, La Motte-Picquet.
What's that supposed to mean?

Fields.MenuText: What's with the glare?
I mean you have a distinctive personality.
I mean what I said. You're peculiar.

Fields.DialogueText: I feel insulted, so I'm upset. Once I have processed it I will not be.
Oh... Okay. I suppose that could be the basis of a flattering remark.
Well, I do not appreciate that adjective.
I didn't mean to upset you. You're simply different from others I've met.
I do make an effort to be distinctive. Merci, Capitaine. I'll take your words as an accolade.
Now *they* owe us an apology...
La Motte-Picquet, are you still on your hunt for close-up pictures of the crew?
No, I decided to stop. Much of the crew didn't seem to appreciate my hobby.
I'm sorry to hear that, although I can't say I'm surprised. What are you going to do now?
I have no idea. By which I mean I have several, each clawing at the throat of another.
Enemy ships inbound!
@BATTLE
What I really need is a new photography series to start working on - something that wouldn't invade others' personal space.

Fields.MenuText: What about a series on the ocean?
You could always do a photo series on your favorite captain.
How about imagination? You could do a series on the things you find that required the most imagination to invent.

Fields.DialogueText: As much as I love the ocean, I prefer taking photographs of people.
A bit conceited, don't you think? Merci, mais non.
That feels too abstract for me. Maybe a more literal topic will do.
Well, I tried. I hope you're able to come up with something.
Don't worry. Eventually, something will come to mind.
Maybe some of them will get caught in the crossfire.
The ideas, or--
Yes. All of the above.
La Motte-Picquet, what exactly are you doing?
Sitting and reading? Surely that's not too difficult to surmise.
But must you sit on the edge of the ship?
Oui, I see no problem with it. It's a great reading spot. It reminds me of sailing with such a nice breeze going.

Fields.MenuText: All right then. Just don't give the crew any bad ideas.
You don't find that at all dangerous?
What happens if you fall off?

Fields.DialogueText: Wouldn't dream of it. But I cannot speak for them.
Remember, I am capable of floating, Capitaine.
I'll catch myself. And if that fails, I'll float back up. See, perfectly safe.
Morganas closing in!
Woah!
La Motte-Picquet!
See? I told you I would catch myself if I fell.
By your fingertips. I still think it's a risky place to sit.
@BATTLE
If I only waited until battle to be extraordinary, the novelty would wear off.
I heard there was a bit of a commotion the other night in the dining hall.
Oh, that was nothing.
Really? Because a few crew members said it was a ruckus. What happened?
A crew member and I exchanged some choice words.
You don't say?
Don't mock me! He insulted my intelligence, so I forced him to apologize.

Fields.MenuText: You know, you're really good at getting others to apologize.
Do you think people apologize only because you're intimidating and not because they're sincere?
One of these days, someone isn't going to apologize when you ask. What are you going to do then?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course. It is one of my many talents.
Insincerity is like a lobster, Capitaine. Raise the temperature and it will assume a more pleasing color.
I'll have to go to extra lengths to assert my authority. Heh... I'm only kidding. I have no idea what I'll do. Something spontaneous, doubtless.
Captain, we have Morganas inbound!
We'll be right there!
@BATTLE
Back to the story. After the crew member apologized, we sat down and had a nice conversation. Now we are book swap partners!
Book swap? What's that?
We each read a book. We swap them. We discuss them afterwards.
That's an... interesting... turn of events. I hope the two of you enjoy yourselves.
I finished Brave New World already, so that's off the table. Some H.G. Wells, perhaps... I could use a bit of utopia.
Bonjour, Capitaine! I have a favor to ask.

Fields.MenuText: You're not going to ask me to apologize, are you? I don't even know what I did.
Nothing immoral, right? I need to keep a good reputation.
You want me to be the focus of your photo series. I thought you'd never ask.

Fields.DialogueText: No. You did nothing wrong. Besides, haven't you noticed that I usually yell first and then ask others to apologize?
Of course not. I'm aware of the image you need to uphold.
Hah! Désolée, but your photo series will have to wait.
Okay, so what do you need?
I need a book with work from famous photographers.
Looking for some inspiration?
Exactement!
I'll see what I can do - although we'll have to take care of the incoming Morganas before that time comes.
@BATTLE
Now that the battle's over, tell me a little more about what you're looking for, La Motte-Picquet.
I would prefer if the photographers were American.
Any particular reason?
I've always been interested in the American life, so I'm sure I can find inspiration from them. Open skies, wide, empty plains...
I'll check around and see what I can find.
Perhaps a labor strike or two.
Quite the spectrum.
America.
La Motte-Picquet, one of our travelers onboard had this - it's a collection of Dorothea Lange's photos from the last ten years or so. Would this work?
Would this work? It's amazing! Thank you! I'll be sure to return it in perfect condition once I've finished with it.
I'm happy you're pleased. Let me know if you're in need of anything else.
This should be good for now. Thank you again! Oh, I'm so excited to look through this.

Fields.MenuText: I've never seen someone so excited to look at some photographs.
If I wasn't convinced of your passion for photography before, I certainly am now.
That's good. You should show me your favorite photographs in the book once you've had some time to look through it.

Fields.DialogueText: But they aren't only photographs. They're expressions of art, a look into someone's heart and mind.
Photography is the best way I know to express myself. In a constantly changing world, to freeze a moment in time is to force it to make sense... if only for that moment.
I trust you know what you just signed up for, Capitaine!
Unfortunately, your photos will have to wait. Morganas inbound!
@BATTLE
Ooo, I'm going to go look through these photos right away!
I'm sure you'll have fun.
Ah, Capitaine, just look at this picture! See how she sits on the roof of her car without a care in the world...
She certainly looks like she'd be fun company.
Does she remiiiiind you of anyone?
She certainly sits like you. I've yet to see your portfolio, of course...
I am nothing without it, Capitaine.
You will not be disappointed!
Don't you look comfortable with your cigar and your book?
I am. Very much so.
What are you reading? I'm surprised to see it isn't the photography book.
I'm making my way slowly through that, savoring every new photograph as I come to it. This is a recent play. Anti-war. Certainly a page turner.
The White Plague. Interesting title.
Did you want a drag?
No, thank you. Where did you get the play?
My book swap partner traded it with me. He's had this copy since before the premiere. He was a stage manager prior to the war.

Fields.MenuText: Do you find it ironic that you're reading an anti-war play on the front lines?
This play isn't going to cause you to leave us, is it?
Maybe this play will give you a broader perspective.

Fields.DialogueText: I believe that's why it seemed so appealing to me at first.
Of course not, Capitaine. I am loyal to you. Besides, it's what I'm built for.
I'm hoping so. I read not only for knowledge but to gain different outlooks on life.
There's the alarm, La Motte-Picquet. Come on.
Just a moment, let me find my bookmark...
@BATTLE
Salut, Capitaine!
How's it going, La Motte-Picquet?
Splendidly! I wanted to show you some photos from the Great Depression series.
Okay, let's see them.
Here, this one, and this one. Oh, and back on this page, as well.

Fields.MenuText: What a somber time. Such struggle and despair.
It's amazing how some people were still able to smile during such a time.
Her photos capture an immense amount of depth in her subjects.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, and seeing it play out in these photos makes me feel as though I am there in that moment.
Never underestimate the power of optimism... and sheer, desperate grit.
I only hope that my photographs could one day capture a similar level of depth.
It is an intense series.
The plight of the Americans during the Great Depression was intense, indeed. And it's started me wondering...
About what?
About how such storms are weathered. The Morganas return stronger for each defeat. They are forces of nature, after all.
Another time for certain. Enemy ships inbound!
@BATTLE
Material conditions and governance... now, those have causes and effects. It is a conversation for another time, of course.
How has your inspiration been coming, La Motte-Picquet? Have you settled on a theme for your next photo series?
Actually, I have.
And what did you decide on?
Well, it was jointly influenced by The White Plague and the Great Depression photo series.

Fields.MenuText: You gained inspiration from your two loves: reading and photography.
An anti-war play and photography about the Great Depression. Sounds cheery.
That play had quite the impact on you, didn't it? I might have to read it myself.

Fields.DialogueText: Media are meant to be mixed!
Try living in the conditions they depict. The audience must be forced to reckon with them.
That would be wonderful. I could ask my book swap partner if you could read his copy.
All right, enough waiting. What is this series you have planned?
Hold that thought, Capitaine. Morgana ships incoming!
@BATTLE
All right, I'll tell you now, although I fear you've built up a little too much anticipation. My series will be about the war we're fighting, and about its effects.
That sounds promising. What do you plan on calling it?
There's a quote from the play I plan on referencing. Something along the lines of "...to make sure there are no more wars to fight..."
Something along those lines?
More or less. War isn't just shooting and shelling, Capitaine. You find it anywhere people are denied a living.
Well, you've got to start somewhere.
Narrow the focus to broaden the message... truly a puzzle.
First day on assignment, I see. What are you taking pictures of today?
*CLICK*
I want to get some photos of the ship.
*CLICK*

Fields.MenuText: Are all those angles really necessary?
What exactly are you trying to capture?
I could never be a good photographer. All I see is a ship, nothing special.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui. I'm not sure which one will be the best in the end, until I have all of my photos together.
I want to get a shot of the ship looking as though it's looming over us, as though danger is imminent.
Of course you can. All you need to do is figure out what you are trying to capture and look for it in the shot.
I hope you're able to get what you're looking for.
*CLICK*
A few of these shots will have to work, I'm sure.
Morganas inbound! Everyone prepare for battle!
*CLICK*
Freeze, everyone! Stay right where you are!
*CLICK*
*CLICK*
La Motte-Picquet!
One more shot!
*CLICK*
Okay, continue as you were! Merci beaucoup!
@BATTLE
Bonjour, Capitaine!
Hello, La Motte-Picquet. What's on the agenda for today?
I'm taking photos of the weapons on board the ship.
Which weapons? All of the weapons?
As many as I can before running out of film.
What are you trying to capture in these photos?
The severity and intensity of war, I think.
The weapons are a perfect choice, then.
That's what I was aiming for.
That's the alarm. You'll have to aim for something else, for a little while.
@BATTLE
Still at it?
Guns at rest are different from guns resting. Does that make sense, Capitaine?

Fields.MenuText: After battle versus simply stationary, right?
Aren't those the same thing?
Is it the guns or is it their environment?

Fields.DialogueText: Precisely. Admittedly, some of the why is more accessible to one who can feel them firing.
Are your legs quite the same after a hard run?
A salient question indeed! The answer, as is generally the case, begins "Yes, and..."
It really does change the way you look at the world, doesn't it? Photography?
I'd be a poor photographer if it didn't. We are often spoken of as passive observers, but the choice of what to depict and how can be seismic.
Some things don't truly strike me until I look at them through this trusty Tiranty.
So it's about showing what you've learned. You've got to be surprised before you can surprise others.
And you are full of pleasant ones today, Capitaine! I'll have to crib that for my own book one day.
Everyone, action stations! Morganas inbound!
What a perfect opportunity to get some candid shots!
*CLICK*
That includes you too, La Motte-Picquet!
Oui, Capitaine!
*CLICK*
I'm almost done, I promise.
*CLICK*
Now, La Motte-Picquet!
*CLICK*
These are great, everyone! Keep up the good work!
*CLICK*
La Motte-Picquet!
*CLICK*
Oui, Capitaine?
Get to your station now.
I'm going, I'm going!
@BATTLE
La Motte-Picquet...

Fields.MenuText: I do not appreciate you undermining my authority, especially in front of crew members.
You should be punished for your blatant disobedience.
While I hope you were able to get a few good photos, you need to be more attentive to my orders.

Fields.DialogueText: Désolée, Capitaine. Truly, I am very sorry. I did not mean to mock you, but obtaining those photos was vital...
Whatever you feel is necessary, Capitaine. I only ask that you take a look at today's work.
A capitaine's orders are first in the heart of every Belle, however circuitous our means of fulfilling them. Besides, I think you'll find these worth the delay.
Time is money, La Motte-Picquet, not to mention lives.
Merci, Capitaine! Take all the time you need.
Having said that...I will of course be confiscating these photos for temporary examination.
What a sight this is.
What sight would that be, Capitaine?
You, off to the side, reading with a cigar and not enjoying the party.
I don't even know whose birthday it is.
What are you reading anyway?
Of Mice and Men.

Fields.MenuText: Come on, join the party. The words of John Steinbeck will not go anywhere in your absence.
You've been working hard on your photo series. This is a great way for you to take a break.
Don't be an outsider. Come and mingle with the others.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm at a pivotal point in the story! There is no putting this down until it's been resolved.
I'm currently trying to do just that.
I don't appreciate the name-calling, even if that is probably the impression I'm giving others.
All right, fine. I'll come.
Thank you.
Oh, look, it's my book swap friend. I'll go talk to him!
*ALARM*
And I suppose I'll be the one to deal with the Morganas...
@BATTLE
La Motte-Picquet, how's everything going?
Wonderful. I've finished another book, meaning I get to start another!
I've been meaning to ask you about the flower you wear in your hair.
Oh, this? It's a lotus, my favorite flower. I grow them in my room.
Do you? I had no idea. Why is it your favorite?
Other than its inherent beauty? I feel a connection with what it symbolizes.
Strength, right? I think I heard that somewhere, although I can't remember where...
Strength, c'est vrai. It also symbolizes grace and passion.

Fields.MenuText: If that isn't the perfect flower for you, I don't know what is.
You do seem to embody those things, La Motte-Picquet.
You've found your flower twin. Now we need to find mine.

Fields.DialogueText: French I may be, but certain aspects of myself are Indochina through and through.
I like to keep a lotus close to me at all times, to remind me of who I am.
Haha! I'll be on the lookout for the perfect flower for you.
Enemy ships inbound!
All right, La Motte-Picquet. Let's put those qualities of yours to good use.
@BATTLE
Salut, Capitaine!
You're looking resolute. How much left of the photo series do you have left to complete?
Only have one final set of photos. The grand finale, if you will.
And what comprises this grand finale of yours?
Morganas incoming!
I'll tell you in a moment. Things need to burn.
@BATTLE
La Motte-Picquet!
Oui?
I received reports that you were taking photographs during the battle. I thought I made it clear I will not have it endanger the lives aboard this ship.
But, Capitaine...

Fields.MenuText: Surely you realize the harm such actions could have caused.
I need to know that I can rely on you, La Motte-Picquet!
Were you anyone else aboard this ship, I'd have thrown you in the brig by now.

Fields.DialogueText: They were the final photos I needed for my series, Capitaine. I couldn't pass up the opportunity.
No one was hurt. I took the necessary precautions to ensure that everyone would remain safe.
I can go sit in the brig, if it would make you feel better. I could use the rest, if I'm honest.
I'm disappointed in you, La Motte-Picquet.
Disappointment is temporary, Capitaine. Art is eternal, and some things lost in the heat of battle should be as well.
I suppose you think you can philosophize your way out of this.
My record speaks for itself, Capitaine. Ask any of the gunners. You'll find I work hard to make it sing.
Capitaine.
Refusing to speak to me isn't the most mature response.
I am very sorry. I brought you a lotus flower as a peace offering.
Really!? You're going to ignore me!
I'm sorry for getting angry. That was uncalled for.
First, you should wait until after I've finished chewing my food before deciding to have this sort of conversation with me.
Ah... yes. My apologies.
Second, do you understand that under no circumstances are you to take such risks during a battle again?
... Oui, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: All right. Then, let's do our best to move past this.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Capitaine. You will not be disappointed.
I suppose I've said my piece. Let's get moving.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: You've said that before.
You can have this conversation with me or you can have it with Zurich.

Fields.DialogueText: My prowess might sway them more than you know, on and off the battlefield.
It has always been true.
*ALARM*
You're finished taking your photographs, correct?
Oui. How do you like the hoa sen?
Hoa sen? Is that Vietnamese?
Oh, right. Yes, it is Vietnamese. I was asking about the lotus flower.
It is an impressive flower. You speak Vietnamese?
Vâng! I speak a few languages.

Fields.MenuText: This is news to me.
Clearly.
Any other secrets you're holding back?

Fields.DialogueText: I've been lost in European and American literature lately... I suppose it never came up.
I'm most fluent in French and English, obviously. But I hope to be at least conversational in the Empire's other tongues.
No, but would I answer differently if there were?
So, what other languages do you speak?
I speak a bit of Wolof, Cambodian, and Vietnamese. An interesting combination, I know.
Maybe you'll find an opportunity to put your language skills to good use during the war.
That would be nice. Some languages are more difficult than others... depending on your enemy, some could make devilishly hard codes.
Don't the Morganas have one?
Not one humans would want or need to hear. Some things are best left to us.
Ugh... my radio room's seizing up. Speaking of Morganas...
@BATTLE
Capitaine! Seeing as you were interested to learn that I spoke other languages, I wanted to show you some of the souvenirs from my travels.
All right, let's see them.
Formidable! This is a handcrafted Balinese mask from Indonesia.
Look at those colors - they're so vibrant.
I also have this traditional tea set from Hong Kong, as well as a handmade fan from Japan.
That is quite the tea set, La Motte-Picquet. We should put it to good use, sometime soon.
This final one is a handmade Merlion miniature stature from Singapore.

Fields.MenuText: I do think these make you a certified world traveler!
What's your favorite part about traveling?
Next time you're traveling, maybe get me a souvenir as well?

Fields.DialogueText: I do try to travel whenever I can! And a good souvenir is no mere decoration.
The approach. The first time I set my eyes on my destination. Everything is so new and unknown. I love that feeling of mystery.
Of course, Capitaine! I'll find one suitably...authoritative.
Captain, we have Morganas headed our direction!
We'll be right there!
@BATTLE
Perhaps one day we'll have a souvenir from one of them.
You'd really want one?
It does not have to be pretty to be educational.
Capitaine!
Yes, La Motte-Picquet?
My book swap friend and I are looking to expand. I think you should join us.
Join... The two of you?
Oui! Of course. We can read and swap books, then discuss them. Our discussions have been rather intense, actually.

Fields.MenuText: I don't have much time to be reading books for recreation.
I don't enjoy heavy books. And I mean the literal and figurative definitions of the word 'heavy.'
I wouldn't say I'm the best at analyzing the meaning of books.

Fields.DialogueText: Not a problem. We can wait on you. Just read in your free time.
Oh, no worries! We'll start off light, I promise.
We'll keep the first few discussions relatively drama-free.
Fine, fine. We can do a trial run and see how it goes.
Great! Here you can read this first. It's The Great Gatsby. Look, it isn't even that long.
I know this book is heavier than you'd have me believe, La Motte-Picquet. But I'll read it anyway.
Save it for when the smoke clears, Capitaine. We have uninvited guests!
@BATTLE
Salut, Capitaine! I have another favor to ask of you.
And what would that be?
I'm trying to make a darkroom to develop my photos.
So you need some supplies.
Precisely. The first thing I need is a small room from which I can shut out all light.

Fields.MenuText: There's an empty closet near your quarters. You could use that, if you like.

Fields.DialogueText: I know precisely the space you mean!
I'd suggest checking the kitchen.
Great idea!
For having taken all the photos you need, it looks as if you still have quite a bit of work in front of you.
You're right. Which means the sooner I start, the better.
You'll have to wait a little bit longer. Enemy ships inbound!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Hence "darkroom."
Sounds delicate. Can you do it safely?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sure I can find a space we aren't using in the cargo hold. I'll have to personally outfit it.
Certainly not during battle, so this will be a time-consuming step in my creative process. One false move and I could spoil a whole roll.
Now, I've gathered almost everything else, expect bins for the necessary chemicals.
So I was thinking...
Congratulations.
I'm kidding, I'm kidding! Please, continue.
You're so funny. Anyway, I was thinking that, since you've put so much work into your photo series...
... and since the series incorporates so much of the ship and the crew, having a little showcase for your work might not be a bad idea.
A showcase? Oh, Capitaine, I think that would be a wonderful idea!
I thought you would. You continue developing your photographs, and I'll set up the area for the showcase here on the ship.
That would be fantastic. Just fantastic. And I'm sorry for making fun of you earlier.

Fields.MenuText: As you should be.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll make it up to you by putting the space to magnificent use.
There's the alarm. Think you can use your excitement as fuel to take down a few Morganas?
Absolutely.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: And to think you can't bear a little name-calling.
Accepted. I know you mean it.

Fields.DialogueText: The novelty of needling you did wear off quite quickly.
I try to be as aware of myself as of my surroundings.
*ALARM*
Morganas incoming, Captain!
Action stations!
@BATTLE
Now that we've finished with them, I have an important matter to discuss with you, La Motte-Picquet.
Oh dear, what happened?

Fields.MenuText: Someone's been spying for the enemy.
Unfortunately, the showcase has to be canceled.
A Morgana just boarded our ship.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh my! Do you have any leads? I'll look into them myself if I need to. I'm very persuasive.
Wha-!? Oh... Okay. I understand that we're at war and things happen...
... I know for a fact that they cannot do that.
Hahaha! I was only kidding, La Motte-Picquet. Just a little revenge for you insinuating that I never think.
I think your sense of humor leaves something to be desired, Capitaine.
Hahaha, I know, and I'm sorry. I do actually have a question for you, though.
What is it?
What type of cake do you like?
Cake!? We're having cake!? Oh, um, chocolate. I love chocolate cake.
I'll keep that in mind, then.
How's the showcase planning going?
I have everything under control. Just make sure you give me your photographs as soon as you're finished developing them.
They will be ready momentarily! Oh, I'm so excited!
Welcome, La Motte-Picquet, to your showcase!
Oh, goodness! Look at this, all my photographs! And chocolate cake! You did all this? Merci, I'm very impressed.

Fields.MenuText: I had a lot of help from the crew.
Thank you. Bringing everything together was a little stressful, but I think we did a good job.
I'm glad you like it. A lot of hard work went into this.

Fields.DialogueText: You'll have to tell me who, so I can properly thank them.
I'm sure you had it all under control the entire time.
I don't just like it. I love it.
As I made my last rounds I looked through your photos and, I have to say, you have some incredible talent.
Oh merci, merci. Which one ended up being your favorite?
I do like the one you took of me. I must say, I look quite commanding.
Hah! Hardly a surprise.
I'm not even ashamed to say it.
It does happen to be one of my favorite photographs as well.

Fields.MenuText: ... is quite the photographer. It will be fun having her on my side.
